1.1. BACKGROUND

The impacts of climate change in Zimbabwe are already being felt throughout all socio-economic sectors. The last three decades have seen increased variability in the seasonal distribu•on of rainfall, an increase in day-•me and night-•me average temperatures, increased incidences of intense rainfall interspaced by long dry spells, and late onset and early cessa•on of rains. These varia•ons in rainfall and temperature are having profound impacts on agricultural industry, food security, hydro-energy genera•on and downstream climate sensi•ve economic sectors. There is ample evidence that climate is a major driving factor for most of Zimbabwe's socio-economic ac•vi•es such that Gross Domes•c Product (GDP) is •ghtly linked with rainfall pa©erns (Zimbabwe Na•onal Water Policy, 2012). Livelihoods of the poor, par•cularly women who are highly dependent on climate sensi•ve sectors such as agriculture, are likely to be impacted by climate change in various ways. Climate change impacts are also expected to disproporonately aﬀect the poor, young, elderly, sick, and other marginalized popula•ons.

Thus it is important to ins•tute robust measures that will translate the challenges into business opportuni•es that could posi•vely transform Zimbabwe's socio-economic fabric. Such measures must necessarily include the integra•on of climate and climate change informa•on into all relevant Government policies and also be in accordance with global eﬀorts to address climate change such as the United Na•ons Framework Conven•on on Climate Change (UNFCCC), in which Zimbabwe is a signatory. To this end, this Na•onal Climate Policy provides a framework for addressing climate related challenges that Zimbabwe faces now and in future due to the changing climate. It forms the basis of developing Ac•on Plans for naonal eﬀorts on adapta•on and mi•ga•on, providing a pla•orm to unpack and implement Zimbabwe's Na•onally Determined Contribu•on (NDC) that will contribute to the global goal of limi•ng temperature rise to below 1.5⁰C.

This Na•onal Climate Policy seeks to provide an overarching framework to give the country basic principles and guidance under which the Na•onal Climate Change Response Strategy (NCCRS) and other climate related strategies will be implemented. This policy is expected to assist the country to meet its Na•onally Determined Contribu•ons (NDCs) to the UNFCCC, create resilient communi•es and drive the country towards an economy that is largely decoupled from clima•c varia•ons. It calls for the climate proofing of other policies and socio-economic infrastructure; strengthening of climate change governance; increased educa•on and awareness; improved early warning and climate services; research to inform planning and future policy orienta•on; as well as a robust sustainable climate finance framework. The Policy is the culmina•on of a highly par•cipatory process bu©ressed by the results of science. Its implementa•on is expected to be based upon the same principles. The policy lays the basis for increased coordina•on and par•cipa•on of all stakeholders in response to the climate challenge.
